SiC-doped Yb2O3 structure (Yb2O3/SiC) was prepared to enhance the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance of Yb2O3 nanofiber, which have been performed by using catalyst in the presence of eosin-Y dye and triethanolamine, called photosensitizer and electron donor, respectively under solar light with/out cellulose and chitosan. In this study, cellulose and chitosan were used as biotemplates to increase the hydrogen production of Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. Bioorganic-inorganic structures, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC, were obtained by simply adding cellulose and chitosan to the reaction cell without any additional treatment. Cellulose and chitosan also used as a mediator for dispersion, hydrophilicity, morphological transformation and adhesion to semiconductor with the help of functional groups. The hydrogen production rate of bare SiC, bare Yb2O3, Yb2O3/SiC composite have been measured as 391 μmol g−1, 818 μmol g−1 and 1685 μmol g−1, respectively. Moreover, the hydrogen production rate of cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC composites were came up to 3346 μmol g−1, 4084 μmol g−1, respectively. These results have been showed that the Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst showed higher activity in the presence of cellulose and chitosan. The existence of biopolymers will create a new field in photocatalytic hydrogen production studies with the advantages mentioned above, thanks to the functional groups. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biopolymer Biotemplate Bioorganic-inorganic structure Hydrogen evolution Lanthanide group transition metal oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen energy, one of the renewable energy sources, is considered the most promising candidate to solve the energy problem, due to its superior properties. Numerous methods have been adopted to produce hydrogen such as steam reforming of hydrocarbons, electrolysis of water, fermentation, gasification of biomass, and photocatalytic hydrogen production [1–4]. In the photocatalytic energy conversion, which attracts attention due to its efficiency and ease of application, semiconductor catalysts sensitive to ultraviolet, visible and solar radiation are frequently used to reach hydrogen, which is a green energy source, in an economical and environmentally friendly way. Many different types of semiconductors such as, oxides, nitrides, sulphides, carbides and phosphides, have been studied as photocatalysts for hydrogen evolution via water splitting [5–8]. Lanthanide group transition metal oxide-based semiconductors, is one of the most frequently studied catalysts in catalytic studies recently [9]. Herein, Yb2O3 nanofiber with a band gap of 3.32 eV was chosen as the catalyst due to its high thermal stability and oxidation properties [10]. Yb2O3 exhibits electrochemical redox properties such as ZnO, TiO2 and provides a great advantage in catalytic studies such as increased electron-hole separation, charge transfer efficiency [11]. The effects of ZnO/Yb2O3 composite materials on the degradation rate of phenol were studied under UV light [12]. In another study, the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of the synthesized ZnO–CeO2-Yb2O3 nanocomposite on different dyes was compared under sunlight illumination, and also the antibacterial effects on Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus bacteria were studied [13]. Yb2O3/g-C3N4 composite obtained by adding lanthanide oxides for the surface modification of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) displayed enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate and high rate of nitrous oxide removal performance [14]. In this study, the photocatalytic activities of the Yb2O3/SiC catalyst prepared by the electrospinning method were examined in the absence and presence of cellulose and chitosan biopolymers. SiC is used as a visible-light-driven photocatalyst for water splitting due to its 2.4 eV (1.23 eV < Eg < 3.0 eV) band gap, extraordinary reducibility feature, high conductivity and suitable conduction band level [15–17]. However, the photocatalytic performance of SiC is limited by its high recombination rate, low surface area and low stability [18,19]. The loading of SiC to Yb2O3 is improved the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity by reducing recombination rate, increasing surface area and stability. Cellulose and chitosan biopolymers also enhance the HER activity by creating high specific surface area and catalyst stability [20]. A lot of techniques are available to integrate inorganic semiconductors into biopolymers, such as chemical vapor deposition, sputtering laser deposition, hydrothermal and sol-gel which are expensive and require labor, time and equipment [21,22]. In this study, it is achieved by directly adding the biopolymer to the reaction cell during the photocatalytic HER. In recent years, biopolymers have been used in many photochemical studies such as dye degradation, water disinfection and water splitting due to their unique adjustable optoelectronic properties. The use of inorganic semiconductors with biopolymers is both an economical and environmentally friendly process. Cellulose is the most abundant, renewable, biocompatible, biodegradable and sustainable biopolymers in nature due to containing of hydroxyl, carboxyl, ester and ether groups [23–25]. It is also insoluble in water because of its fibrous, rigid structure, intra- and inter-molecular hydrogen bonds between glucose units in a cellulose chain [26]. Chitosan shows hydrophilic, insoluble in solvent, weak base, hydrogen bind forming, salt forming and chelating with metals characteristic qualities [27]. Owing to these features of cellulose and chitosan, it provides various applications in the fields of adsorption [28], photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants [29], heavy metal removal [30], pervaporation [31], dye removal [32], fuel cell [33], solar cell [34] and hydrogen production [35]. Although pristine cellulose does not show photocatalytic activity, it increases the hydrogen production activity of semiconductors with as mediator function for electron transfer [36] or biotemplates [37,38] due to its large surface area and porous structure. In the hydrogen production, biopolymers accelerate the reaction rates in the aqueous media due to its fibrous structure, excess and diversity of functional groups on its surface, hydrophilicity, and morphology transformation. Moreover, functional groups on their surface can act as scaffolds to disperse and fix catalysts through chemical interactions [39,40]. Therefore, the aforementioned properties of biopolymers make them a promising template for photocatalytic water splitting [38]. In this context, many biopolymers have been used to increase the photocatalytic activity by extending charge transfer ability and stability properties of the photocatalysts [41]. The interaction between biopolymers and semiconductors increases light absorption, charge transfer efficiency, stability of the structure and large surface area [20]. There are studies carried out with bioorganic-inorganic structures in the literature, but most of the studies have been reported to bind to the biopolymer in a synthesis stage before the reaction and then undergo hydrolysis during photocatalytic HER. In this study, SiC loaded Yb2O3 nanofiber, Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst, has been prepared by electrospinning method. Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst showed 2.05 times higher hydrogen production activity than bare Yb2O3 nanofiber. Moreover, cellulose and chitosan were used for the first time as mediator function for electron transfer and biotemplates to increase the hydrogen production efficiency of Yb2O3/SiC catalyst in the photocatalytic HER under visible light irradiation. The morphological and structural properties of Yb2O3/SiC, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC catalysts were clarified with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Molecular structures of Yb2O3/SiC, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC catalysts were clarified X-ray diffraction (XRD). The optical properties and band gaps calculation of catalyst were performed with UV-Vis and diffuse reflectance methods, respectively. In addition, after HER, the distribution of catalyst elements was visualized SEM-Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX) method. By adding biopolymers to the reaction medium without any pretreatment, hydrogen production was successfully increased by being used as a biotemplate and mediator for the semiconductor catalyst without undergoing hydrolysis. Recently, the integration of bioorganic-inorganic photocatalysts, biyopolimer-Yb2O3/SiC will create a new field for photocatalytic applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 The synthesis and characterization of materials Yb (CH3CO2)3· 4H2O (99.95%) and Polyacrylonitrile (Mw = 150 000 g mol–1) were supplied by Aldrich. N, N-Dimethylformamide and Silicon carbide (SiC) (99.5%) were purchased from Isolab and Nanografi, respectively. Triethanolamine (TEOA, 97%), cellulose, chitosan, hydrochloric acid (HCl), potassium hydroxide (KOH) and eosin-Y (EY) dye were provided by Sigma-Aldrich. 2.2 The synthesis of Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst Yb2O3 nanofibers were produced as in the study previously published by our working group [10]. In the synthesis of Yb2O3/SiC nanofibers, 0.5 mmol YbAc3 (Yb(CH3CO2)3·4H2O) and different rates of SiC (1, 3, 5, 7 and 9% of Yb weight) were mixed in 5 mL of DMF (N, N-Dimethylformamide). Then, 500 mg PAN (Polyacrylonitrile) was added to this mixture and this solution was stirred overnight. The obtained homogeneous solution was loaded into the syringe having a 21-gauge metal needle and placed in the syringe pump. A rotating collector lined with aluminum foil was put opposite the syringe pump, and the distance between them was adjusted to about 15 cm. A voltage of 18 kV was applied to the metal needle, and the collector was grounded. The speeds were set as 1 ml/h for the syringe pump and approximately 20 rpm/min for the rotating collector. In this way, the whole solution was coated on the collector, and raw fiber was placed in the oven for heat treatment. The heating rate of the oven was set at 5 °C/min, and fibers were crystallized at 500 °C for 1 h. 2.3 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments The photocatalytic activities of prepared materials were performed in the Pyrex reaction cell (135 ml), closed with rubber septa at room temperature. Before the photocatalytic activity tests, the aqueous 5% TEOA solution, used as an electron donor, have been bubbled with nitrogen gas to obtain oxygen-free solution. 10 mg synthesized catalyst, TEOA (deoxygenized, pH:9, 5%, 20 mg, 0.33 M) as an electron donor and EY dye as a light absorber (1.3 ml, 0.33 mM) added into the reaction cell in the glove box, oxygen free environment [42]. After the closing of reaction cell with rubber septa, sonicated for 5 minute to obtain dispersed catalyst in the TEOA and EY mixture. Reaction cell has been located on the magnetic stirrer in front of the solar light (Xe Lamp 300TM, λ ≥ 420 ). The produced hydrogen gas, which is accumulated in the head space of the reaction cell, was taken hourly and its amount measured with gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2030). In the photocatalytic activities of biopolymers, the optimum hydrogen production was determined in the same experimental conditions by adding different amounts of cellulose and chitosan (1 - 9 mg) to the biopolymer amount optimization. Then, the solar to hydrogen conversion efficiency (STH) was computed according to the Eq. (1): (1) STH % = Δ G ∘ x R H 2 PxA × 100 Herein, RH2 and ΔG0 shows the hydrogen production rate, mmol s−1 and the standard Gibbs free energy of water splitting, 237 kJ mol−1, respectively. Furthermore, P and A indicates the irradiation power density of incident light and the irradiated area by the incident light, cm2, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization results Phase analyses of Yb2O3/SiC catalyst was performed with XRD method and the XRD patterns were given in Fig. 1 comparatively. The XRD patterns were indexed with standard diffraction cards numbered 00-043-1037 for Yb2O3 and numbered 01-078-2780 for SiC. It was determined from these diffraction patterns that the main peaks at 29.6, 34.0, 49.2, and 58.5° correspond to the (222), (400), (440), and (622) planes of the Yb2O3 nanofibers [10]. It was also seen that the diffraction peaks at 35.8, 41.6, 60.2, and 72.1 belong to beta SiC, and these peaks were matched with (006)/(102), (104), (110), and (116)/(202) planes, respectively [43]. As can be understood from Fig. 1, the XRD graphs of Yb2O3/SiC composites produced at different rates are similar to the diffraction pattern of Yb2O3 nanofiber. When the amount of SiC is increased to 5%, SiC peaks begin to appear in the diffraction patterns. However, the peaks of SiC are seen at low intensities in the XRD pattern due to the high amount of Yb2O3, and the dominance of its peak intensities compared to SiC. In graphs, the peaks of Yb2O3 are shown with asterisks and SiC with squares. The chemical valance state of Yb2O3/SiC was analyzed with XPS method. The obtained high resolution XPS spectrums were given in Fig. 2 . According to these results, the peak belonging to the O 1s spectrum at about 531 eV was deconvoluted to three peaks called O1, O2, and O3 (Fig. 2a). Herein, O1, O2 and O3 were attributed to O atoms in the Yb2O3 [44]. High-resolution C 1s XPS spectra were shown in Fig. 2b and fitted to three peaks corresponding to C-C, C-O-H and C=O peaks. The energy positions of these peaks were determined as approximately 284.1 eV (C-C), 285.5 eV (C-O-H), and 288 eV (C=O) [45]. Si 2p spectra of Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst given in Fig. 2c were fitted, it was understood that the main peaks at 100.9 eV and 101.4 eV consisted of four characteristic peaks. These peaks were assigned to Si-Si, Si-C, O-Si-C, and SiOx species, indicating that Yb2O3 materials bonding strongly to SiC materials formed a composite [45]. High-resolution Yb 4d spectra include four singlet peaks at approximately 184.5 eV, 187.7 eV, 192.4 eV, and 198.1 eV. The peaks at 184.5 eV and 198.1 eV correspond to 4d5/2 and 4d3/2 spin-orbit-split, while peaks at 187 eV are associated with Yb2(C2O4)3 formation [10]. The post-photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction XPS spectra have been also investigated below in order to tracked the structural stability of catalysts. UV-Vis analyses were performed to investigate the optical properties and calculate the band gaps of nanocomposites (Fig. 3 ). The optical properties were analyzed by diffuse reflectance measurements and the obtained graphs were given in Fig. 3 as inset figure. It is understood from these graphs that composites exhibit similar reflectance behavior between 300 and 800 nm. Data obtained from the diffuse reflectance spectrum were used to calculate the Kubelka-Munk function. These functions were used in the Tauc Equation, and band-gap energy diagrams were plotted [10,46]. The band gap values of nanocomposites containing %1, %3, %5, %7, and %9 SiC were estimated as 3.07 eV, 2.95 eV, 2.92 eV,2.60 eV, and 2.69 eV, respectively. The morphological properties of Yb2O3 nanofiber-based composites were investigated by SEM. SEM images of nanocomposites consisting of different amounts of SiC were given in Fig. 4 . These images show that nanofibers have homogeneous diameter distributions. However, it was determined that the homogeneity of the fibers is preserved up to 5%, and after this rate, there are deformations in the fibers. As a result of the calculations, the diameters of Yb2O3 nanofibers were specified as about 87.4 nm for %1, 69.4 nm for %3, 85.4 nm for %5, 147.5 nm for %7, and 242.2 nm for %9. Also, it was seen that SiC particles added to Yb2O3 nanofibers fasten on the fibers or fill the inter-fiber spaces as an agglomerate. 3.2 The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution experiments results The photocatalytic HERs have been performed in the presence of EY dye and TEOA, as photosensitizer and electron donor, respectively under solar light illumination. The optimum study pH of aqueous media adjusted to pH 9, as reported previous studies [42,47]. First of all, the Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst did not produce any hydrogen in the reaction medium without EY dye. The photocatalytic HERs of Yb2O3/SiC catalysts which contain different amount of SiC (1, 3, 5, 7, 9%) were carried out and hydrogen production amount of concentration are given in Fig. 5 . The hydrogen production amounts of 5% Yb2O3/SiC, bare SiC, bare Yb2O3 semiconductors were compared in Fig. 6(a) . According to these results, the produced hydrogen of bare SiC was attained from 298 μmol g−1h−1 to 391 μmol g−1 after 8 hours light irradiation. SiC is valuable material for water splitting under visible light because of band gap (2.3 eV) and band position [48]. However, the photocatalytic activity is limited due to its high recombination rate and high surface exchange rate [49]. Hydrogen production of bare Yb2O3 semiconductor attained from 239 μmol g−1h−1 to 818 μmol g−1 after 8 hours in the same conditions. Moreover, the produced hydrogen by Yb2O3/SiC composite was attained from 316 μmol g−1h−1 to 1685 μmol g−1 after 8 hours of photocatalytic reaction, which is 4.3 times and 2.05 times than those of pristine SiC and Yb2O3, respectively (Fig. 6(a)). Besides, the produced hydrogen of Yb2O3/SiC composite was measured 2673 μmol g−1 after 24 hours. According to the results of UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy of the aqueous solution, the characteristic absorption peak was measured at 520 nm before the reaction (Fig. 6(b)). After 8 hours of hydrogen generation reaction, degradation of EY dye shifted its characteristic peak to 490 nm. Moreover, Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous photocatalyst demonstrates higher absorbance peak than those of SiC and Yb2O3 catalysts, which is interrelated with photostability of catalysts [50]. The photocatalytic hydrogen production result of reusability experiment of Yb2O3/SiC catalyst were shown in Fig. 6(c). Even at the end of the third irradiation cycle of Yb2O3/SiC, its maintained more than half of its hydrogen generation activity. Numerous investigations on SiC-based photocatalytic hydrogen evolution have been performed in the literature to improve the activity of hydrogen evolution [51–53]. For example, different morphologies of SiC nanomaterials were exposed to UV-Vis light to achieve enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution generation [48]. Au loading on SiC nanoparticle improves the hydrogen evolution activity by enhancing light absorption and creating localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR), which is provided enhanced light absorption [54]. Loading of SiC nanoparticles on the ultra-thin graphene nanosheets (SiC/GSs) improved the hydrogen evolution activity by largening surface area, enhancing light absorption and charge transfer [49]. SiC @Zn0.5Cd0.5S core shell nanocomposite has displayed enhanced HER by reducing shell thickness which result in both inhibited recombination and increased separation of charges as well as decreased photoluminescence [55]. However, until now, it has not been reported that there is a study related to the photocatalytic hydrogen production activity of the Yb2O3/SiC nanocomposite catalyst obtained by loading the SiC to the Yb2O3 nanofiber structure by the electrospinning method. When we look at the photocatalytic hydrogen production studies with SiC in the literature, hydrogen production activities have increased significantly in the presence of lanthanide oxide-based catalysts with or without biopolymers (Table 1 ) In order to increase efficiency and stabilize the rate of hydrogen production efficiency of Yb2O3/SiC, cellulose and chitosan biopolymers were used in the same reaction cell. Cellulose and chitosan used as a biotemplate and mediator for semiconductor dispersion, hydrophilicity, morphological transformation and adhesion to semiconductor with the help of functional groups [56,57]. Cellulose and chitosan do not produce hydrogen absence of EY in the reaction medium shows biopolymers cannot absorb light. Presence of EY biopolymers reduce the hydrogen production activity of bare EY which shows the biopolymer do not act as a catalyst. The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activities of cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC composites were measured as 638 μmol g−1h−1 and 696 μmol g−1h−1, respectively. Photocatalytic hydrogen production rates of cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan- Yb2O3/SiC composites were reached to 3346 μmol g−1, 4084 μmol g−1 after 8 hours of photocatalytic reaction, which were enhanced approximately 2 times and 2.5 times than that of Yb2O3/SiC, respectively (Fig. 7 ). Cellulose and chitosan, which are used as biotemplates, increase the hydrogen production efficiency of catalysts by creating an adhesion surface and increasing the active sites and by providing facilitated charge transfer, improved charge separation and inhibited recombination of reduced electron holes thanks to the aforementioned supporting functionalities [20,39,58,59]. In the literature, some cellulose and chitosan based photocatalytic studies were carried out to enhance hydrogen evolution activity due to their large surface area, being natural biotemplate and consisting of different functional groups properties [41,59–62]. Moreover, STH conversion efficiency results of Yb2O3/SiC, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC, chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC catalyst were calculated as 0.54, 1.08 and 1.32, respectively. To further confirm of chemical valance state of chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC and cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC catalysts after photocatalytic HER, XPS analyses were investigated. As a result of these analyses, the obtained high resolution XPS spectrums were given in Fig. SI 1. As can be seen from Fig. SI 1 (a, f), the peak belonging to the O 1s spectrum at about 531 eV was deconvoluted to three peaks called O1, O2, and O3. Herein, O1 was attributed to O atoms in the Yb2O3, while O2 and O3 were attributed to C=O and hydroxyl groups in biomaterials (chitosan and cellulose), respectively [10,63]. High-resolution C 1s XPS spectra were shown in Fig. SI 1 (b, g) and fitted to three peaks corresponding to C-Si, C-C, and C-O-H peaks. The energy positions of these peaks were determined as approximately 284.1 eV (C-Si), 285.5 eV (C-C), and 287.7 eV (C-O-H) [45]. When Si 2p spectra given in Fig. SI 1 (c, h) were fitted, it was understood that the main peaks at 100.9 eV and 101.4 eV consisted of four characteristic peaks. These peaks were assigned to Si-Si, Si-C, O-Si-C, and SiOx species, indicating that Yb2O3, SiC, and biomaterials formed a composite by bonding strongly to each other [45]. High resolution XPS spectra of Yb 4d belonging to chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC and cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC were given in Fig. SI 1 (d, i). These results reveal that Yb 4d spectra include four singlet peaks at approximately 184.5 eV, 187.7 eV, 192.4 eV, and 198.1 eV. The peaks at 184.5 eV and 198.1 eV correspond to 4d5/2 and 4d3/2 spin-orbit-split, while peaks at 187 eV are associated with Yb2(C2O4)3 formation. The interactions of ytterbium acetate and biomaterials may have caused Yb2(C2O4)3 formation [10]. Since chitosan contains N atoms in its structure, N 1s spectrum was obtained as a result of XPS analysis of chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC. According to this high-resolution spectrum, the main peak at 398.5 eV were deconvoluted three peak. These peaks at about 396.5 eV, 398.5 eV, and 401.5 eV were correlated to SiNx, N(-SiOx)3, and C-NH species belonging to biomaterials [63]. Additionally, SEM and SEM-EDX analysis were performed to confirm of surface morphology of biotemplated catalysts after photocatalytic HERs (Fig. SI 2). In these SEM images, chitosan, chitosan-SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC structures were seen clearly in Fig. SI 2a, b, c, respectively. Cellulose, cellulose-SiC and cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC structures were also seen in the Fig. SI 2d, e and f, respectively. In the surface of the chitosan and cellulose, SiC and Yb2O3/SiC structure were seen clearly which is supported by the SEM analyses was performed before the photocatalytic HER Fig. SI 2a and d, respectively. Furthermore, the presence of the biopolymers in the biopolymer-Yb2O3/SiC structure which obtained after the photocatalytic HER were confirmed by elemental mapping analyses (Fig. SI 3). These results confirm the previous studies and shows the addition of catalyst to biotemplate surface have been carried out successfully. These results show that, the chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC structure contains O, C, Si, Yb, N elements and cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC structure contains O, C, Si, Yb elements. According to Yb/C and Yb/N ratios the amount of cellulose and chitosan were found as 0.15% and 0.67%, respectively. It is clearly seen that chitosan biotemplating is happening more effective than cellulose biotemplating which is in accordance with photocatalytic hydrogen evolution results. Because cellulose and chitosan hydrolysis cannot occur in the case of photocatalytic HERs reported in the literature [64]. XPS, SEM, and SEM-EDX methods performed after photocatalytic HERs demonstrate that biopolymers are acted in the biotemplate function and confirm that harsh pH conditions are required for the occurring hydrolysis. 3.3 Proposed mechanisms for the photocatalytic HER The suggested hydrogen evolution mechanism of biopolymer based Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst were demonstrated in Fig. 8 . Herein, EY absorbed the photons under visible light irradiation and photogenerated electrons excited from HOMO (0.89 V vs. NHE) to LUMO (-1.1 V vs. NHE) level of EY [65]. Excited electrons can be transferred to biopolymer, Yb2O3 or SiC from sensitizers’ LUMO. These excited electrons can be used in three distinct water reduction reaction pathways by transferring from (i) biopolymer (cellulose-chitosan) to Yb2O3, (ii) Yb2O3 to SiC and (iii) biopolymer (cellulose or chitosan) to SiC. In the presence of biopolymer, fibrous structure, excess and diversity of functional groups on its surface accelerates the reaction in the water splitting system. Moreover, functional groups on its surface can act as scaffolds to disperse and fix catalysts through chemical interactions resulting in improved photocatalytic hydrogen production efficiency [26]. At the same time, TEOA can be regenerate the excited form of EY by supplying electron. Consequently, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC composites exhibits enhanced hydrogen production rate, which is about approximately 2- and 2.5-times than pure Yb2O3/SiC, respectively. Cellulose and chitosan, which are used as biotemplates, increase the hydrogen production efficiency of catalysts by creating an adhesion surface and increasing the active sites and by providing facilitated charge transfer, improved charge separation and inhibited recombination of reduced electron holes due to the supporting functionalities [28]. 4 Conclusions The Yb2O3/SiC nanofiber, was successfully fabricated by electrospinning method and biotemplated with cellulose or chitosan in the photocatalytic HER by sensitized with EY dye because of wide band gap. The photocatalytic HER activity of Yb2O3/SiC nanofiber composite was increased by addition of cellulose or chitosan to reaction the medium. Cellulose and chitosan used as a biotemplate for semiconductor with the help of synergistic effect between biopolymer inorganic catalyst. These results have been showed that the EY sensitized Yb2O3/SiC catalyst showed higher activity in the presence of cellulose or chitosan. Both cellulose and chitosan increase the activity of hydrogen production by both facilitating the electron transfer mechanism and creating an adhesion surface to the catalyst. The results can be attributed to the roles of cellulose and chitosan in the photocatalytic water splitting reaction as mediator and biotemplates. The role of biopolymers, enhance the photocatalytic activities of biotemplated catalysts were proven by using different morphological and structural techniques. Moreover, their morphological and optical results support a biotemplate role of cellulose and chitosan in photocatalytic HER. coredata.dc:description: SiC-doped Yb2O3 structure (Yb2O3/SiC) was prepared to enhance the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance of Yb2O3 nanofiber, which have been performed by using catalyst in the presence of eosin-Y dye and triethanolamine, called photosensitizer and electron donor, respectively under solar light with/out cellulose and chitosan. In this study, cellulose and chitosan were used as biotemplates to increase the hydrogen production of Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. Bioorganic-inorganic structures, cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC, were obtained by simply adding cellulose and chitosan to the reaction cell without any additional treatment. Cellulose and chitosan also used as a mediator for dispersion, hydrophilicity, morphological transformation and adhesion to semiconductor with the help of functional groups. The hydrogen production rate of bare SiC, bare Yb2O3, Yb2O3/SiC composite have been measured as 391 μmol g−1, 818 μmol g−1 and 1685 μmol g−1, respectively. Moreover, the hydrogen production rate of cellulose-Yb2O3/SiC and chitosan-Yb2O3/SiC composites were came up to 3346 μmol g−1, 4084 μmol g−1, respectively. These results have been showed that the Yb2O3/SiC nanofibrous catalyst showed higher activity in the presence of cellulose and chitosan. The existence of biopolymers will create a new field in photocatalytic hydrogen production studies with the advantages mentioned above, thanks to the functional groups.
coredata.dc:title: Biotemplated silicon carbide-loaded ytterbium oxide: Effective catalyst for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions
